Title: Why is Euler's Totient function always even?
Content: I want to prove why $\phi(n)$ is even for $n>3$. So far I am attempting to split this into 2 cases. Case 1: $n$ is a power of $2$. Hence $n=2^k$. So $\phi(n)=2^k-2^{k-1}$. Clearly that will always be even. Case 2: $n$ is not a power of $2$. This is where I am unsure where to go. I figure I will end up using the fact that $\phi(n)$ is multiplicative, and I think I'll get a $(p-1)$ somewhere in the resulting product which will make the whole thing positive, as $p$ is prime implies $(p-1)$ is even.
AcceptedAnswer: You can do it via the formula as you do, but you can also simply use the definition that $\phi(n)$ is the number of numbers $k$, with $1 \le k \le n$, such that $\gcd(n, k) = 1$. Clearly, if $\gcd(k, n) = 1$, then $\gcd(n - k, n) = 1$ as well, so (for $n > 2$) all the numbers relatively prime to $n$ can be matched up into pairs $\{k, n-k\}$. So $\phi(n)$ is even.

Euler's totient function φ(n) counts the number of integers up to n that are coprime with n. So, we need to show that this count is even whenever n is greater than 3.

The user already split it into two cases: when n is a power of 2 and when it's not. For the first case, if n = 2^k, then φ(n) = 2^k - 2^(k-1) = 2^(k-1). For k ≥ 2 (since n > 3, so k ≥ 2), 2^(k-1) is even. That checks out.

Now the second case where n is not a power of 2. The user mentioned using the multiplicative property of φ(n). Right, φ is multiplicative for coprime integers. So if n has prime factors other than 2, we can factorize n into its prime components. Let's say n has a prime factorization of 2^a * p^b * q^c... where p, q, etc., are odd primes.

If n is even but not a power of 2, then it has at least one odd prime factor. Let's take one such prime p. The φ(p^b) = p^b - p^(b-1) = p^(b-1)(p - 1). Since p is an odd prime, p - 1 is even, so φ(p^b) is even. Therefore, φ(n) would be φ(2^a) * φ(p^b) * ... which includes an even term, making the entire product even.

But what if n is odd? Then n has no factors of 2. So n is an odd number greater than 3, not a power of 2 (since all powers of 2 except 2^0 are even). So n must have at least one odd prime factor.
